text:
True to the theme of this mini-essay, I had this epiphany while reading an article by @simonsarris.

Inspired, I wrote an open-mode Twitter thread about my thinking. Then I went into closed-mode, did some research, and refined my original ideas.

https://t.co/DeWhjeq3f7

There are two kinds of creative work:

1) Open Mode: A state of creative play where you have fun and follow what's interesting.

2) Closed Mode: A state of focus where you work towards goals, ignore distractions, and do what your to-do list tells you to do.

Here's my mini-essay. https://t.co/MTZikg6nTG

text:
In closed mode, you walk the dog.

But in open mode, the dog walks you. 

Because of that, you have to surrender to the randomness of the world and listen for the seeds of creativity. They start as intuitions, and like a flower in the early spring, they take time to blossom.

A couple years ago, @michael_nielsen said to me: “Being distracted is underrated as a goal. Being productive is overrated as a goal. Almost all the best ideas come out of being distracted and unproductive.”

Open and closed mode is a good articulation of why that’s insightful.

text:
The problem with traditional productivity advice is that it doesn’t take open mode seriously. But that’s because closed mode is easier to define, and therefore, easier to write about. 

Here’s how John Cleese of Monty Payton write about it.

(h/t @simonsarris) https://t.co/tF0Q4HQufD

Creatives have two kinds of working: open mode and closed mode.

Open mode: A state of unfocused play where you discover new ideas.

Closed mode: A state of focused work where you work towards a specific outcome.

Like breathing, you inhale in open mode and exhale in closed mode.

"Practically, how does this strategy work for you?"

Samples: I tweet all the time, and published 114 email newsletters this year.

Appetizers: This year, I published 73 articles.

Main Course: I published two long-form essays this year — and both were written to be evergreen.

Find a mix of samples, appetizers, and main courses that works for you.

As you do, you'll balance the consistency needed to grow an audience with the quality you need to deepen those relationships at scale.

https://t.co/QoEgoa4xf9

Samples are like tweets. Make them small and publish all the time.

Appetizers should be fun and awaken the audience's appetite for your ideas.

Main courses should be unforgettable and of exceptional quality. They're the meat of your work, but people need time to get there.

Online writers should serve three plates of ideas:

1) Samples: Quick ideas that grow your audience by giving people a taste of what you do.

2) Appetizers: Short articles that people can share and try out.

3) Main Course: Long-form essays that are the bedrock of your worldview.

urls.title: The Perks of Niche Fame - David Perell
urls.description: There are two kinds of fame: Celebrity-Fame and Niche-Fame.

text:
People who are Niche Famous are well-known in a small circle of influence but virtually unknown outside of it. 

Their relationships with fans are built upon shared interests and instead of being widely-known, they’re well-respected. 

https://t.co/6RqzkKKsn6

When we talk about fame, we usually think of Celebrity Fame. 

But the Internet inspires an alternative, which I call Niche Fame — which gives you many of the benefits of fame without the terrifying downsides.

Here’s my mini-essay. https://t.co/yysJSTMw3W
@aman_fullstack Nice! What’s the source?

On the topic of identity, this is a wild prediction from “The Crypto-Anarchist Manifesto” which inspired parts of modern Internet culture.

It predicts that reputation will become more important, even as the way we verify identity changes.

If so, anonymity will be a new normal. https://t.co/CPyjKZvvVB

When we pursue optionality, we avoid bold decisions. Like anything meaningful, venturing into the unknown is an act of faith. It demands responsibility and the spine to push through uncertainty.

But a life without conviction is a life controlled by the futile winds of fashion.

Young people today are trained to pursue optionality as an end in itself, which leads to a fear of commitment and a generation of wandering souls. 

I can't recommend this essay enough.

https://t.co/nr5RxfAYYg https://t.co/W4gwrS6r9e
My life improved dramatically once I stopped chasing optionality and committed to the things that mattered to me most

text: @TariqMK_ @MargRev by @tylercowen

There's never been a better time to be a conscious news consumer. The Internet is filled with high-quality information, so savvy people have access to more high-quality ideas than at any point in human history.

Here's my 15,000 word essay on the subject.

https://t.co/iCUBZLUqId

Growing up, I read three newspapers every morning. In the age of information scarcity, we didn't have much of a choice.

But in our present age of information abundance, it's better to follow a wide swath of human curators who aggregate individual links from a variety of sources.

One of the worst habits instilled by Mass Media is the idea that you should tune into the same program every day at the same time.

Diversify your information sources instead.

Punctuation is to writing as music is to movies.

Music, like punctuation, exaggerates the mood.

text:
The better you define your tasks, the more efficiently you can do them.

It’s called the Law of Mechanical Turk: “Any project, if broken down into sufficiently small, predictable parts, can be accomplished for awfully close to free.”

(h/t Seth Godin)

https://t.co/J4nAJzVlw4

“How can I delegate my tasks?”

1) Outline the vision. 
2) Share resources. 
3) Describe your definition of done. 

Source: https://t.co/i8qeGRUKg1 https://t.co/ny7RzqjzEO

If you work for yourself, I strongly recommend reading this article from @nateliason. It’s called “The Personal Leverage Loop” and it’ll instantly change the way you think about your work. 

Define, refine, automate, delegate. 

https://t.co/OBkFlhEsvj https://t.co/WJY7KkYbW1

Instead of working harder, increase your productivity by operationalizing using as much of your work as possible. Then, delegate your recurring tasks.

Here’s a list of my operations checklists. https://t.co/RO6u9X9vvA

text:
"Why the boxes?"

We were inspired by the branding of the "Conversations with Tyler" podcast. I liked the distinctiveness of @tylercowen's boxes, particularly because they meshed so well with the early versions of the site's design.

The end result is simple, but very memorable. https://t.co/aSfzBSuPzw

"Why the logo?"

We started with a conversation about what I stand for: writing, creativity-inspired play, a passion for aviation, and bold visions of a better future. We iterated, and iterated, and iterated some more.

Here's what some of the original designs looked like. https://t.co/FR72BYHbuT

"Why the purple?"

We wanted something that was distinct, sophisticated, and instantly recognizable. Once we found the right shade of purple, we implemented it across the site. Doing so simplifies design decisions and nearly guarantees a cohesive look. 

https://t.co/YVirbBRElA
@KyleTibbitts @photomatt Amazing how a good team can fix my utter design incompetence 🙃

text:
“[Screw] the casual viewer. Seriously, who wants a casual viewer? If you’re a writer do you want a casual reader? I don’t want those people. Don’t want ‘em. Throwing them back. They’re like little fish on the hook. Throw ‘em back.”

— David Simon, creator of The Wire.

“The trick to good writing is: identify the one person you’re writing for and write only for them.

If you don’t think they will benefit from what you put out, scrap it. When you don’t focus on one person, your writing has no focal point and can’t scale.”

— @mrsharma
@mrsharma Exactly! So, so true. https://t.co/QIxq6exU2Q

Newsletters should be as simple as a postcard.

In New York, most of the best *new* public spaces are private — in apartment buildings and skyscrapers.

But I saw an alternative when I visited Australia in 2018. There, a higher percentage of the prettiest spaces are public like the Bondi Beach pools outside of Sydney. https://t.co/g5VE7Kah91

We rave about technological progress, but are we creating beautiful cities at the same rate?

And if not, then why? https://t.co/Z1oLdwFpBt
One hallmark of a great city is public spaces that use beauty to bring people together, and Bethesda Terrace in New York is as good as it gets https://t.co/8fuy8kzVQr

text:
I want to live in "full-screen mode."

Instant access to all the world's information fragments our attention and every study I've seen about multi-tasking shows how unproductive it is.
@Rameshoflondon Say more... what do you have in mind?
@_phelma oooooo, I like that!

Obsessing over seconds and minutes robs us of the ability to fall into flow states. 

I'm the worst offender. I almost always know exactly what time it is (+ or - 10 minutes), which contributes to a low-grade ambient anxiety that many of my friends share.

https://t.co/bawIz24Ogm

I want to remove clocks from my life as much as possible.

I dream of only having only one clock in my house. Instead of telling the time, it'd toll only three times per day.

1) 9am: Time to start creative work

2) 12pm: Time to start non-creative work

3) 10pm: Time to sleep
RT @nathanbarry: How to Start Building Your Email List @david_perell https://t.co/9gYKXVM78k
@DevamAcharya Those are my favorites too

I play rave-style electronic music whenever I write my first drafts because it takes me out of my mind. Dancing and singing puts me into a generative state, which gives me the raw material. 

Only later do I turn those nascent ideas into (hopefully!) refined prose.

text:
This instinct to write about enormous topics is rooted in anxiety.

Almost every writer is pressed for time and feels like they haven’t written enough. They’re scared to narrow their thesis, out of a fear that others will call them an imposter if they’re not comprehensive enough.

Surfing the Internet will make you think everything is easy. Programs like “six minute abs” are enticing, but ultimately self-defeating because the carrot of easy gains is actually a mirage.

As Bezos explains, it’s better to be candid about the difficulty of a challenge.

text:
The practical implication of this belief is that I’m less concerned about my innate interests than most people. Instead, I surround myself with passionate people and follow their lead.

Only later, once I’ve learned to appreciate something, do I ask: “Am I interested in this?”
@pittman021 It’s pretty!

You rarely go on Wikipedia and say “I didn’t understand the article because it was so poorly written,” but that’s the base case for reading academic papers. Wikipedia is proof that complex ideas can be explained without a complex writing style.

One of the most impressive things about Wikipedia is that it repeatedly produces clear writing.

Their editing guidelines double as excellent writing advice:

1) Don’t argue from authority

2) Avoid acronyms

3) Consider the inverted pyramid strategy https://t.co/fYy3x53SUf
@thechaz I’d argue it’s what @tylercowen does with his podcast, and it works splendidly

One of my driving assumptions in life is that you can develop an interest in almost anything if you have the right people teaching you about it.

Where critics work with a posture of well... criticism, fans make the world come alive by sharing knowledge. We need more of them!
The writing world is filled with critics, but I wish it had more fans — people who spend their entire lives helping others appreciate an art form

text: Internet forums like Twitter aren’t very good at responses like “you’re mostly wrong, but you’re wrong in very interesting ways that could eventually be productive, so let’s work together to improve your thinking” which is the kind of collaboration that fosters creativity.

One of my biggest worries about the Internet is that the feedback loops are too fast. 

Thinking differently requires years of independent wandering, which often looks unproductive in the short-term even when it leads to long-term breakthroughs. The Internet may inhibit this.
I know it sounds too simple to be true, but one of the best ways to foster innovation is to make it easier for people to be radically different

text:
People like to say that “you have to look for the magnificent in the mundane,” but it’s not as true as the cliche implies. 

The joy of adulthood is that it’s intensely *interesting.* My career is a quest to maximize interestingness, and share the joy of that quest with others.
Specifically, you should use the Webster 1913 Dictionary https://t.co/DWMmlpuuO1

If you’re writing and unsatisfied with a word, skip the Thesaurus and use an old dictionary instead.

Old dictionaries have wonderfully precise definitions which will generate more creativity and contain more soul than the average thesaurus.

Here are some lovely definitions. https://t.co/357KAgJDhD

Surely, the magnificent has a place in adulthood but not like it does in adolescence.

As an adult, you confront the idea that everyday moments are the stuff of life. Rituals, routine. All that jazz. Maturity marks a transition from lusting for grandeur to relishing the everyday.
The transition from youth to adulthood is the end of chasing the magnificent and the beginning of appreciating the mundane

This paragraph from @nntaleb shook me, first for the dangers of specialized knowledge and eventually, for shamelessly following your curiosity instead of learning what you “think you should be learning” https://t.co/ZqRE4ss7x5
The Savior on the Spilled Blood church in St. Petersburg is one of the most magnificent pieces of architecture I’ve ever seen https://t.co/biPVeOJhSj

https://t.co/i224IDaoe9
@joshfrank @TaylorPearsonMe @seanogle @TropicalMBA If it’s has to do with golf, I’m always down
I'm reminded of this line from @patio11: "The amount of money flowing through capitalism would astound you. The number and variety of firms participating in the economy would also astound you."
The more I interact with high-level people, the more I use a heuristic of "they have way more money and way less time than you think."

When starting my writing school, I deliberately named it “Write of Passage” instead of naming it eponymously. I want it to become the business school of the future, and that’s more likely if has a life beyond me and others eventually take the reigns.

https://t.co/czfDDCRv54

For inspiration, creators should be looking at Glossier (valued at $1.2 billion) and Primal Kitchen (sold for $200 million). 

Both companies started with individual creators, but eventually transcended them and generated tons of wealth as a result.

text:
If you’re a creator, launching a company under your own name is a sure-fire way to make a quick buck. But visionary creators will build companies that transcend their personal brands so they can hire leadership as it becomes successful.

Example: Dave Portnoy and Barstool Sports.

Creators are relatively well-positioned to sell products with high customer acquisition costs, where they can leverage their distribution advantages. Right now, creators tend to play in commodity markets where their names are a stamp of approval. 

(h/t @tweettal + @blakeir)

Paul Graham has a famous essay called ”Makers Schedule, Manager‘s Schedule” where he shows that different people have different ways of working. The same is true for wealth generation. Generating short-term cash and building long-term equity are different mindsets.

text: The problem with being directly paid to share ideas online is that if you don’t publish, you don’t get paid. But creators have two valuable resources: trust and attention. They should use that influence to build companies that grow in value once their creator-career is over.
The creator economy is shifting from thinking of itself as a cash-generating industry to an equity-building one, where creators can build wealth that grows once they stop working
@BMBernstein Oh, good old Erewhon

There’s a eerie similarity among office lobbies around the world.

Big words are lovely because they’re so descriptive and descriptiveness is one form of clarity. 

Whenever you use a big word, you make an implicit tradeoff between the benefits of sharper communication and the drawbacks of limiting the number of people who will understand you.
When writing, you should use big words when they help you communicate clearly but if you’re using them to impress people, delete them

Minimalism is the path of least resistance, where everything that could stir up controversy is removed.

The problem with it is that it’s boring. Not Apple, with its tasteful balance of wood and glass. But all the copycats who’ve copied its design have none of Apple’s feng shui.

Another one of my unpopular opinions about writing is that tangents rock.

Staying on topic strips your writing of soul and strips it of life until it reads like legalese. But tangents reveal a writer’s personality, so I give you permission to use them as long as they’re punchy.

Get to the point when you write.

Skip the backstory. Define terms quickly. Assume your reader is smart and resourceful.

I know that’s the opposite of traditional writing advice, but it’ll make your writing so much better.

Professional sports is special because we get to watch people achieve their lifelong dreams in public.

By living vicariously through them, their happiness becomes our own.

My favorite philosopher of the clock is Lewis Mumford.

• The clock is the key machine of the Industrial Age.

• The clock cuts time into discrete pieces, as clock towers become the soundtrack to human life.

• Clocks synchronize the masses, but removes them from organic life. https://t.co/bWz6n6hBD8

Before the clock, we lived on naturalistic cycles.

Night followed day, day followed night; and each year had a succession of seasons. Spring was for planting and summer was for harvest. But then, the clock arrived.

This old Roman poem speaks to the tyranny of the clock. https://t.co/ZhGvJjZUWf
@JohnathanBi Where’d you find a digital copy?

@BlackForestBoi Information overload doesn’t exist. 

It’s actually a byproduct of bad information management systems. https://t.co/XZvBT0tAPn
@GregBrooksOH Peter Turchin talks about this idea well

Information abundance, like all markets of abundance, are bad for the average person but great for a small number of people.

My favorite metaphor is health, where obesity rates and the number of people in incredible shape are *both* rising.

I call this the Paradox of Abundance. https://t.co/tQIWStpiu8

@patrick_oshag Information abundance, like all markets of abundance, are bad for the average person but great for a small number of people. My favorite metaphor is health, where obesity rates and the number of people in incredible shape are *both* rising.

text:
Big caveat: I still work *extremely* hard.

Intellectually, I want more leisure. But at the same time, busting my ass for the past five years has improved my life tremendously.

Brunello Cucinelli, who I wrote about below, strikes a wonderful balance of leisure and hard work. https://t.co/YdwH9CI6P8

Future obsessions will scratch their heads when they see how work consumed early 21st century life, even for people in the highest tax brackets.

Here are two excerpts from an excellent book called “Leisure: The Basis of Culture.” https://t.co/KlAMCIBOvV
@DimaKritchevski That’s good pushback. There’s an important piece of nuance here that I need to think about, thanks!

The word school comes from the Latin word: skola.

It translates to leisure. But it’s not an American sit back and watch TV leisure. It’s a laugh with friends, read great books, listen to marvelous symphonies, and contemplate life’s most important questions kind of leisure. https://t.co/zM5eThgDHP

text:
There are two kinds of education, but we treat them like the same thing.

1) Vocational training: Schools should help students find a job quickly.

2) Becoming cultured: A high-minded approach centered around art, music, and philosophy.

Finish #1, work for a bit, then start #2.

Conventional wisdom says that more education is better.

But I think we need less. 

People should be able to find their first jobs with 12-18 months of vocational training. Then, once they're financially stable, we should encourage them to continue their education.
@ChrisHarveyEsq @schlaf @beondeck 🙏🏼🙏🏼

I love the German word: Fingerspitzengefühl

The literal translation is "finger tips feeling." It describes somebody with extreme situational awareness, who has strong intuitive instincts in complex situations.

They act with tact in social situations and foresight in business.
@JoshuaLisec That’s not true, at least for the ones I know personally
@p_millerd @alexeyguzey @jeremygiffon, @iAmLikelyWrong, @JohnathanBi, @PresentWitness_, @KevinSimler are all must follows

One example is Oswald Spengler who wrote more than 100 years ago.

He was an average teacher in an average school, but his book “Decline of the West” was a bestseller in Europe throughout the 1920s.

He presents a theory of history unlike anything I’ve read. 

(h/t @jeremygiffon) https://t.co/5MWWm96s21

My favorite writers are non-academic academics.

They study with the seriousness of a college professor, but write with the freedom of a retired one.

text:
The Amish also have “early adopters” who can use new technologies, with permission.

Based on how that person behaves, the community decides how they want to use the technology. https://t.co/q7QPlYXXVm

Two ideas stand out: The Amish want technologies that direct their attention to the community, and second, they don’t want to serve technology so they make technology serve them.

Here’s the original quote from Kevin Kelly’s beautiful interview with Krista Tippett. https://t.co/spl4fPaDDm

The Amish ask two questions before they choose to adopt a new technology.

1) Will this technology strengthen my family?

2) Will this technology strengthen our community?

Maybe we should do the same.

text:
Imposter syndrome plagues many writers, so I asked Seth about it.

Seth shared a lesson from Isaac Asimov, who is one of the most influential science fiction writers of all time.

He wrote from 6:30am - 12pm every day. No matter what his subconscious said, he kept typing.

With that routine, he published ~400 books in his lifetime. https://t.co/E3g4ZmFzNs

text:
I like the word "freelancer."

It literally translates to "a sword for hire."  Originally, it referred to medieval mercenaries who fought for whichever country paid them the most.

Today, the sword is a good metaphor for the sharp specialization that defines a freelancer's work.

Here's a telling quote: "If we can impair the cognitive control abilities of people we're trying to judge, we’ll do a better job of sussing them out: they will be less able to confuse our cheater-detection systems."

(h/t @nateliason for the link)

https://t.co/kv5x7Hv0pr

Here's a crazy theory: Alcohol is a social technology for trustworthiness.

We get drunk with people to see how they act when they lose some control. They reveal themselves once they've had a few drinks because their powers of deception are inhibited.

Small changes in word choice can change the meaning of a sentence without you realizing it.

Once you see it, you’ll see it everywhere.

I like the idea of “muting the world.”

Every now and then, when things get particularly crazy, you turn off the news and retreat into a nook with trusted friends and great books.

Don’t shirk your responsibilities but don’t buy into the manufactured dramas either.

My motto for the weekends: “Follow the soul.”

On the weekdays, I focus on projects and goals. But on the weekends, my life becomes slower and more contemplative. 

It’s like changing gears: The to-do list disappears so I can waltz along a trail of leisure.

Nintendo's philosophy can improve your writing.

While the rest of the Internet is talking about the latest Netflix show or a hot new book, you can pull from old and under-valued ideas instead.

I call this "Lateral Thinking with Withered Ideas."

Here's my mini-essay. https://t.co/EaHoow5rqj

For basically all of human history, high status people worked the least.

Now it’s the opposite. https://t.co/8Q4xeW5u6Y

In 1967, a Senate subcommittee was told that by 1985, the average American would work only 22 hours a week, for 27 weeks per year.

But the opposite happened.

Today, Americans work almost four more weeks per year than they did in 1979.

The mechanical clock was invented in the 12th century to rally the monastery to prayer.

But the West’s relationship with time transformed in the 14th century, when the first public clock tower was built and challenged our rhythms of work and rest.

What a marvelous passage. https://t.co/qONWURTQlN

Spacial memory is a big reason why my note-taking system is so valuable.

It’s not just that all my notes are saved in the same location. It’s that I move through my notes like I move through a familiar city — each “neighborhood” activates a new part of my memory.

Here’s the research from Joshua Foer, a former world memory champion.

• Memory champions rely upon visual memory and spatial navigation.

• By building a memory palace, you can place abstract ideas in familiar places, which helps you remember them. 

(h/t @farnamstreet) https://t.co/f2dNFkIZUG

We remember physical books better than Kindle ones because memory is spacial.

Instead of storing every idea in our head, we outsource memory to our environment. That’s why smart students study for exams in the same place they take the test.

text:
In 2015, I was having dinner with a friend in New York.

She realized I was in a bad mood, but I couldn’t explain why. Then she said: “I think it’s because you haven’t created anything today.”

She was right. 

Since then, I’ve published something online almost every single day.

Building an audience is like building a bridge.

People find you on open platforms, which give you free reach. But you want to help people cross the bridge onto private channels where you can reach people directly.

I call it the Public to Private Bridge.

Here’s my mini-essay. https://t.co/PWFU9LPbtX

RT @the_perell_bot: My love of learning began once I stopped going to school

-@david_perell

A three-step formula for teaching anything:

1) Explicitly state the audience’s flawed assumptions.

2) Tell a memorable story that illustrates your alternative perspective.

3) Explicitly state the takeaways from your story, and show how your way of thinking is more useful.

If you write online, name your ideas.

Make them memorable by making them concrete. It’s hard to know what will stick, so name everything and double down on the ideas people use most in casual conversation.

text:
If you want to improve your writing, sign up for my 7-day email course.

You'll learn how I organize ideas and write Twitter threads like this.

https://t.co/IrqeZcVqwC

14. Live in the relentless pursuit of culture

His self-imposed reading curriculum draws from a pantheon of sages from Socrates to Saint Benedict. He says: "I am very rigorous with myself. You have to take care of the mind with studies, the soul with prayer, and then your body.

13. Heed ancient wisdom

Cucinelli wants to enhance the spirit of his hometown instead of changing it. That means honoring tradition and the essential culture of a place. To improve it, he follows a classical architectural style that's "the physical embodiment of his ideals." https://t.co/U3aC6EnrKm

12. Trust your gut

Cucinelli dropped out of engineering school when he was 24 years old. In business, he avoids moving too fast or being rushed. He likes using cashmere because it can for multiple generations and people don't throw it away. 

https://t.co/jGyi95z0Pw

11. Surround yourself with ancient wisdom.

On the weekends, he keeps technology at a distance so he can look after his soul. He decorates his surroundings with tributes to novelists and Greek philosophers.

"The true way to nurture your soul is philosophy."

(h/t @jeremygiffon) https://t.co/5d9cC2hcJP

10. Stay local

He sources his cashmere from goats in Mongolia, but his headquarters is still based in a small Italian village, where most of his workers live. One 90-year old resident said: “Before, this place was a sh*thole, but Mr. Cucinelli has given the place some dignity.” https://t.co/JUvArDqWrH

9. Transform the pain of your past into beauty in your future

Growing up, Cucinelli saw how unjustly his father was treated at work. After watching him suffer from a "malaise of the soul," he set out to build a company defined by beauty, craft, and fair working hours.

8. Relax on the weekends

Employees aren't allowed to send emails on the weekends, so they can enjoy rest, contemplation, and family time. He quotes Emperor Hadrian who said: “The daily business, the daily life, the daily chores, kills the human being.“

https://t.co/ts2MHfj0xV

7. Share your mission by writing online

Cucinelli shares his philosophies on the brand's website. His essay titles define the company's ethos: “The Decline of Consumerism in Favor of a Fair Use of Things,” “Humanist Artisans of the Web” and “Address to the Masters of Labour.” https://t.co/NVvwYMkE3z

6. Make the world beautiful

His philosophy is a blend of enlightenment and romanticism, which comes to life in his light-filled factory.

His obsession with beauty is so strong that he asks employees to drink out of glasses instead of bottles when they sit at their desks. https://t.co/tnDij3D6D6

text:
5. Give people moral and economic dignity

His whole team enjoys a daily locally-sourced lunch for 90-minutes every day. In service of his values, he built a 16-feet high, 80-feet wide monument which says: "Tribute to Human Dignity."

He says: "Man needs dignity more than bread." https://t.co/tYVT1z4bNP

4. Improve your home town

His company is based in a small town called Solomeo, two hours away from Florence. He's used the company profits to build a theater, a new clocktower, and a school for artisans. 

He wants to create a Borgo dello Spirito — a “Village of the Spirit." https://t.co/4m5X7ArQ3m

3. Fair work never steals people's souls.

Cucinelli says: “I have always claimed that the human being should work a fair amount of hours, that is eight hours a day, and after that it is necessary to devote time to your spirit, your soul and your body."

2. He sets strict working times.

His team starts the day at 8am and have a hard stop at 5:30pm, after which work is forbidden.

He says: “Human beings are much more creative in the morning after a good rest and after devoting time to themselves and their families."

1. He donates 20 percent of profits to charity, through his foundation.

The foundation's mission is “to support any initiative enhancing knowledge, protecting the land and its monuments, highlighting the value of tradition, promoting spiritual and daily values of mankind.” https://t.co/E4dKmhIczS

You should know about Brunello Cucinelli.

He's the billionaire founder of a $450 million fashion brand. His company is valued at more than €1.6 billion, and it's fueled by his radical approach to business.

Smartphones restore the need for extended rest, but they've hijacked our attention so forcefully that we don’t know how to rejuvenate without them.

Menuha is a beautiful Jewish word.

It describes a cheerful restfulness that is rare in the modern world. It’s a time for the body and soul to rest in unison, where anger is lifted and tension evaporates. 

That’s why the Sabbath has two meanings: “to rest” and “to celebrate.”

text:
There’s an idea in poker called “table selection.”

Basically, there are two ways to win more: you can either improve your skills or you can play against weaker players. The metaphor applies to every industry.
@Josh_Ebner 15,000 words

The point isn't that length automatically leads to popularity.

But the belief that people only read short-form articles is a myth. Writing long-form increases the upside and the downside of writing: bored readers will close the tab but entertained ones won't forget your name.

Looking at the page view metrics on my website and only one variable correlates with popularity: My longest essays are the most popular ones.

If you can write well, focus on long-form essays.

CRIBS also works with speaking because you can see the emotions in facial expressions.

People raise their eyebrows when they’re confused, ask you to speed up when you're repetitive, lean in when they’re interested, turn away when they're bored, and gasp when they’re surprised.

Whenever you ask somebody to give feedback on your writing, tell them to follow the acronym CRIBS.

It stands for confusing, repeated, interesting, boring, and surprising.

Here's my mini-article. https://t.co/bfawpJJwA2

As a writer, you will derive the most meaning from essays where your final draft contradicts what you thought before you started writing. 

But most people run away from complexity. When the world doesn’t make sense, they dismiss their ignorance and move onto something else.
@DXF11758588 That's a fair piece of pushback, thank you

When the world does the opposite of what you think it’s going to do, it’s not the world that’s wrong. It’s you.

Here's the key point: The factor causing the world to behave differently than you think is more influential than ALL the ones you’re considering.

I first heard this idea in 2016 while attending an interview with @IAmAdamRobinson. 

He said: "One of the key things to investing is to be aware when you hear a voice in your head that says it doesn’t make sense. That’s where the gold mine is — things that don’t make sense.”

My favorite way to find interesting ideas is to look for things that don't make sense.

When something doesn't make sense, most people turn away and focus on something else. Don't do that. Think of it as an invitation to learn instead.

Here's my short article. https://t.co/mRP1rmJxyP

text:
Bikes, not cars, are the best way to move through cities.

People get to enjoy the outdoors and are forced to interact which builds solidarity among strangers. Spend two days in Amsterdam — where commuting is a blast — and you’ll feel it right away. https://t.co/WGamZnCDn3

Back to cities, I’ve always liked this cartoon about how much space we allocate for cars instead of people.

Technology should serve us, but sometimes, it feels like we forget that and start serving technology.

(h/t @JWellsCFO) https://t.co/TBzRd8QLK2

I’m increasingly convinced that avoiding scale is a recipe for happiness.

Keep a small group of close friends, work with a small team of people, and avoid big companies (yes, there is nuance here). 

Economically, the notion is absurd. Emotionally, it increasingly feels true.

text:
American society is entirely oriented around the car. 

I saw this when I registered to vote last week. To prove identity, the form asked for my driver’s license, not my passport. That’s not necessarily a problem, but it reveals how we serve cars instead of making them serve us.

Right now, I’m living in a suburb of Austin, Texas. I don’t have a car so I’m entirely dependent on delivery workers and my roommates (who have cars) if I want to go anywhere.

Tires, not feet, are the engines of practical reality which makes you feel powerless as a meager human.

One of the weirdest things about modern urbanism is that we build the opposite of what we like.

We adore Europe’s narrow streets, but build skyscraper-lined cities with six-lane roads and sterile shopping malls, that are impossible to walk. https://t.co/sAN51OTRCt

I worry that the rationalist attitude you need to build technology conflicts with the aesthetic one you need to galvanize support.

But humans are motivated less by facts and figures, and more by beauty and wonder. So in addition to building, we have to paint a magnificent future

Today’s technologists are builders who need to become artists.

The world lacks an inspiring vision for how technology can improve it. Without inspiration, we can’t move forward together.

To begin, we should emulate the might and majesty of Art Deco. https://t.co/iJA6tKitwm

text:
The best thing playing sports taught me was how to fail in public and keep going like it doesn't even matter.

One of those lessons you need to learn when you're young.

“The big secret is that there are many secrets left to uncover. There are still many large white spaces on the map of human knowledge. You can go discover them. So do it. Get out there and fill in the blank spaces.”

— Peter Thiel

Access and revelation are earned secrets.

The process of being a writer is living a life that helps you find as many of those earned secrets as possible. Usually, they come from the work you do, the information you consume, or the people you spend time with.

There are two ways to find original ideas to write about: access and revelation.

1) Access happens when you have proprietary information, usually because of your experiences.

2) Revelation happens when you connect public information in new ways, usually because of hard work.
@DavidPessah Match the thesis with this from @mmay3r https://t.co/cIHLfDSfKy
@VecnanKrait You’re a hero, appreciate it
@jmrphy I know him but haven’t seen him talk about writing. Honestly, there’s a part of me that hates writing too but damn, it feels good to publish something you’re proud of
@VecnanKrait That’d be amazing! Thanks
@VecnanKrait Love it! Do you have a link?
@KyleTibbitts Actually writing is either the best part or the worst part, but rarely in the middle of those two extremes

If you want to be prolific, one of the worst mistakes you can make is to start thinking about a topic when you sit down to write about it.

Better to collect experiences passively, take lots of notes, and start writing once your ideas are clear.

I start writing an essay when I’m 80% done with it. 

Once I’ve collected the notes, lived the experiences I want to write about, and structured my ideas during conversations with friends.

text: The people who die with the most regret are the ones who had a creative vision, but never followed through with it

The usefulness of checklists depends on the payoffs of an experience. 

If there’s big upside and low downside, you don’t want checklists. When there’s low upside and big downside, you want a checklist.

24. Question the standard trade offs

Bryson refused to accept that there was a trade off between distance and accuracy. He copied both the world’s long drive champions and the straightest hitters in golf history.

text:
Picasso was once sitting in a park.

A woman saw him and asked if he could draw her a portrait. Picasso agreed, finished it, handed it to her, and said: "That'll be $5,000."

The woman was confused: "But it only took you 5 minutes."

Picasso said: "No, it took me my whole life."

entity.name: The Flash
entity.description: At 11, Barry Allen's life changed completely when his mother died in a freak accident and his innocent father was convicted of her murder. Orphaned Barry later becomes Detective Joe West. Now a crime-scene investigator, his dedication to learn the truth about his mother's death drives him to follow up on every new scientific advancement and urban legend. When his latest obsession - a particle accelerator heralded as a world-changing invention - causes an explosion, it creates a freak storm and Barry is struck by lightning. He awakes from a coma nine months later with the power of superspeed. When he learns that others who have gained powers use them for evil, he dedicates himself to protecting the innocent, while still trying to solve the older mystery.

text:
8. Share your podcasts on Twitter

Create a thread where people can explore key quotes and high-level ideas from your podcast. Quotes are simple because you don’t need to flex your creative muscles to share them. Just transcribe what the guest says.

https://t.co/TecHe80BxB

7. Save time with a production page

Once the guest signs off, I open a production page with all the information my team will need to edit, publish, and promote the podcast. The worksheet takes time, but it reduces all back-and-forth among our team. https://t.co/OG6NOTjCSR

6. The Podcast 2x2

When it comes to explicit interviewing styles, I think of podcasts on a 2x2 axis. One axis is focused on learning vs. entertainment, and the other is about hanging out versus interviewing.

My podcast is 90% learning-focused, 70% interview focused. https://t.co/3CLs5PQT9p

5. Create a quality guest experience

A guest should never feel confused. If they do, it’s our fault. We confirm the podcast recording via email 24 hours before every podcast and email a “Guest Page” with essential details, such as contact and recording information. https://t.co/ZCDSBxkRXk

4. Favor conversation over questions

 No matter how many questions I send, the best questions are unpredictable because they follow-up on a previous answer. Listen for the golden silences in conversation when people express themselves in the absence of words.

3. Write questions in advance

I try to write questions that catch the guest off guard. In a respectful way, never a hostile one. And not because the questions are sharp, but because they inspire an epiphany.

Here are my questions for my interview with @3blue1brown https://t.co/dAYXNbuPvJ

2. Contacting big-name writers

Many writers only do podcasts when they're promoting a book. Email authors right when you hear they’re releasing a new book. When you do, offer to record the podcast early but release it when the book comes out. 

That's what I did with Seth Godin. https://t.co/j7TghA0ep5

19. Ground yourself in timeless ideas

In 2014, Byson almost quit playing golf. He was depressed and unhealthily obsessed. Desperate for answers, he turned to his favorite Bible passage from Colossians 3:23: "Whatever you do, work heartily, as for the Lord and not for men."

18. Perform intuitively

Bryson practices like a scientist so he can play like an artist. Here's what he learned from his hero, Moe Norman: "Why was he able to hit it straight every time? It wasn’t that he was thinking about everything. More like he was thinking about nothing."

17. Keep pushing the limits, even after other people think you’ve made it.

Right after winning the US Open, Bryson announced that he’s going to experiment with a 48-inch driver (3 inches longer than the norm) so he can drive the ball even farther — “maybe 360 or 370 yards.” https://t.co/LdrVNpTEeP

15. Collect more data

Bryson insists on collecting data beyond the driving range. He's the first golfer I've seen that brings his launch monitor onto the course so he can mimic tournament conditions.

With all that data, he can study trends and identify where he can improve. https://t.co/y02X9TsVPo

14. Cutting-edge innovation happens in weird ways

Bryson works out his brain by watching movies. He measures the peaks and valleys of his brain's electrical current, with a goal of staying calm during stressful scenes.

He also monitors his brain activity on the course. https://t.co/PiDwpYzGG4

13. Greatness is grueling

Bryson and his coach Chris Como set up the ideal indoor practice studio. This video shows how he swings as hard as he possibly can to increase his clubhead speed. Note the force plates under his feet and the data at the end of the video.

h/t @GOLF_com https://t.co/OM1T5O3SAD

11. Unique people do unique things, even outside their main area of expertise

Bryson's autograph is as unique as his approach to the game. Even though he's right-handed, he often signs his autograph backward with his left hand. https://t.co/9Y2e25RpU1

10. Measure what you can

Bryson gets instant feedback after every shot on the driving range, which is unprecedented in the golf world.

The data pays off too. With a 200 mile-per-hour ball speed, this drive drive flew 365 yards — more than 3.5 football fields. https://t.co/XMtNL8seBa

9. Work hard

The night before his US Open win, he was the last player on the driving range.

"People don't realize how hard I work to try and get a better understanding of my biomechanics. Right around 14, I started working really hard and that's kind of what changed my game." https://t.co/CS6vuiBpnK

8. Identify the highest leverage ways to improve

Professional golf increasingly rewards people who drive the ball far. But Bryson’s also improved his putting.

When he first turned pro, he was 157th in putting. Now, he’s 12th. Likewise, he’s climbed from 55th to 2nd in driving. https://t.co/wNd86j4D8l

7. Seeing that experts are wrong in one area inspires you to question conventional wisdom in other areas too.

He first questioned conventional wisdom with "The Golfing Machine." Then, he did it by putting big grips on his clubs. Now his goal is to live for "130 or 140" years. https://t.co/yEmAqlC2UL

6. If you’re innovative, people will laugh at you 

Bryson’s been criticized for turning golf into a science. Instead of “trusting his feel,” he pulls from physics and geometry. He’s the only golfer I’ve ever seen who consistently brings a launch monitor to the driving range. https://t.co/JQiAetw4zM

text:
2. Experiment with yourself

Most players have irons of different lengths, but all of Bryson's are 37.5 inches long. Unlike other pros, all his irons have the same swing weight. Their lie angles are 10 degrees more upright than usual, which is why his swing looks funky. https://t.co/DjIfOJbMi8

1. Great ideas are buried in history

Bryson's swing is inspired by a 1969 book called The Golfing Machine. It describes 144 ways you can swing a club and inspired Bryson to adopt a "single plane swing." It's one of the most controversial books ever written about golf. https://t.co/XO1NQeYQPK

Bryson DeChambeau might be the most innovative athlete in the world right now.

He just won his first major championship and is changing how golf is played at the highest levels. People call him "The Mad Scientist of Golf." Here's what you can learn from him.

Here’s a one sentence summary of everything I learned from him: Good debaters talk about facts, great ones talk about framing.

h/t @adilmajid

My friend was a nationally ranked debater, and here’s what he said:

• Give a roadmap whenever you start speaking.

• Signpost every argument.

• Explicitly state the implications of your arguments.

• He practiced speeches until his 5 year-old brother understood the impact.

This post is part of my goal to publish 100 articles in 100 days. 

Sign up here to receive them by email: https://t.co/24YCmA9wwi

https://t.co/KtqjT1On4b

@lennysan @unlocklevels YIKES

Learn to write fast.

At most, it will increase your earnings power because fast-moving companies need people who think fast. At the very least, it will make your writing process more efficient.

The "Islands and Bridges" strategy works particularly well for articles where you have lots of ideas about a subject, but you're not sure how they connect.

It gives you the license to write about one idea at a time, knowing that you can bridge them together at the end.

Writing consists of islands and bridges.

Islands are the core ideas in your article and bridges are the transitions that connect them. Try writing the islands first, as distinct sections. Then, connect them with bridges at the end.

Here's an example from an article I'm writing. https://t.co/QE4JordAb6

Writers battle this psychological quirk every day.

Good writers know how to keep their most insightful ideas fresh, so they can write about them well. To identify your best ideas, even the ones that seem obvious, have conversations with smart people and watch what they react to.

@Aderaido From @jeremygiffon

This would be a great essay topic.

Here’s how I’d write it: First, I’d create a dashboard of social, technological, and economic factors over time. I’d focus on the social factors because they are under-studied and look for epochs where the correlations between them break down.

Progress studies tracks metrics like GDP growth, but we should study social progress more.

Some key factors:

• Family closeness
• Institutional trust
• Depression rates
• Number of close friendships

Key question: When is technological progress at odds with social progress?

text: RT @patio11: I’d tell most bootstrappers to produce an infoproduct (book, course, newsletter, etc) in domain X prior to a SaaS in domain X.…

My point is that sometimes, you don’t find truth by settling in a single interpretation, but by swinging from side-to-side on the hammock of ambivalence.

This is especially true when you’re investigating the soul.

This is some seriously beautiful prose.

“We are ambivalent, in Freud’s view, about anything and everything that matters to us… Where there is devotion there is always protest… where there is trust there is suspicion.“

https://t.co/7d1lUuLhDr https://t.co/fXjSVkQmSw

If you want to dig for insight, look under the ground of paradox — or things that are ambivalent. 

https://t.co/XqNZZ8W8iP

We’ve watered down the beauty of the word “ambivalent.”

In casual speech, it now means that you have mixed feelings about something. 

But originally, it meant that you had *opposed* feelings: Love and hate, focus and distraction, slavery and freedom — which is more interesting.

Benjamin Franklin copied his favorite writers too! 

Here’s what he wrote in his autobiography: “I thought the writing excellent, and wished, if possible, to imitate it.” https://t.co/LGuLl8W5yM

Jack London famously improved his writing by copying Rudyard Kipling. 

He said: “As to myself, there is no end of Kipling in my work. I have even quoted him. I would never possibly have written anywhere near the way I did had Kipling never been. True, true, every bit of it.”

Musicians copy the greats all the time when they practice their scales. It’s boring but it works. The mechanics of music become clear not when you listen to it, but when you play it yourself.

The same is true for writing. https://t.co/iAJ7fRvzmR

There are two insights here: 

1) When you copy your favorite writers, you’ll absorb their style.

2) If you can’t find your voice, copy people and pay attention to moments of resistance. At times, you’ll want to write something different — those moments reveal your unique style.

2) Writing: How to use the Internet to make friends.

3) Writing: Making your ideas work for you 24/7, as they spread across every corner of the globe.
As a creator, it is your job to find your audience — not your audience’s job to find you

"I was writing and now my outline doesn't make sense anymore."

The frustration you feel is a good thing. It means you're thinking thoughts you've never thought before, which is proof of progress.

Then, once you've exhausted your ideas, create an outline

Starting with an outline can be problematic because it can block the creative serendipity that makes writing so productive.

Or, as @paulg once wrote: "Expect 80% of the ideas in an essay to happen after you start writing it, and 50% of those you start with to be wrong."

In school, you learn to start with an outline but I often write mine at the end.

Here's what that looks like:

∙ Write a bunch of little paragraphs with random thoughts on a topic.

∙ Organize them into topics and sections.

∙ Once the structure is clear, I create an outline.

The counter-argument is that time is time — regardless of the medium.

If so, the Lindy Effect is a sliding scale where the best books are old ones that’ve stood the test of time.

I’ve found that it’s mostly true, which is why my book club is called “The Lindy Literary Society.”

I wonder if articles on the Internet are shaped more the Lindy Effect than books. 

Old books are great, but you often pay a tax of bad writing and no context. But online writing has been easy to understand from the beginning.

If so, old articles are even better than old books.

text:
I’m coining a new term: The Line on Wine Glass Principle

The restaurant I just ate at has a line on wine glasses so servers know when to stop pouring, but the line is proof that the business has lost its soul.

This metaphor applies to every company. https://t.co/w5pZMijuq6

@eriktorenberg Recommended! 

https://t.co/gdQ8Tsuhlj

Saying that writing a lot makes you a good writer is like saying that talking a lot makes you a good public speaker.

It seems true, but it’s not. 

Public speakers don’t just talk. They hire coaches, watch themselves on video, and frequently perform in front of an audience.

The importance of re-writing is a subtle point, but it’s stuck with me ever since @vgr wrote about it a couple years ago. 

Editing isn’t usually fun, but it’s how you improve as a writer. https://t.co/nxWJ5L0tsz

Writing a lot won’t make you a better writer.

If it did everybody who answers 100 emails per day would write like Hemmingway.

If you want to improve your writing, listen to critical feedback, read great books, and spend a lot of time *re-writing* your sentences.

text:
@jboogie That’s a good point. I remember visiting Gettysburg in high school and having the history feel alive like it never felt alive in school. 

Same with Berlin, more recently

The inspiration for this idea comes from this excellent essay.

“The essence of the Western idea of progress can be simply stated: mankind has advanced in the past, is now advancing, and may be expected to continue advancing in the future.”

https://t.co/i1SpAqwqH9
@Paul_Johnson Interesting, explain....

The Ancients assumed that humanity was doomed to cyclical time.

But Christian theology sees time as linear.

It moves away from the Garden of Eden, and toward a day of judgement, justice, and the establishment of a New Heaven and a New Earth — the birth of the idea of progress. https://t.co/RKYDkLWI0V
The idea that time is linear, not cyclical might be Christianity’s most important contribution to Western thought

Egyptian hieroglyphics and Roman history felt more like fiction than fact at the time. 

Maybe it’s my learning style: I need context to become excited about an idea, but most of the history I learned in school felt irrelevant to the present day — even though it usually wasn’t!
In school, I would have liked history class much more if we had started with the present and worked back to the past

Writing an essay is a process of working towards your main idea. Whenever my thesis feels unclear, I use these three strategies:

• Draw the idea
• Explain it to a friend
• Send myself a text message

All these stategies have one thing in common: I get away from my computer.
If you’re writing an article, the main idea probably isn’t clear enough until you can draw it

If you’re reading good books and living a halfway interesting life, you’re already having *way more* ideas than you need to write well.  

But you don’t realize how many good ideas you have until you start taking notes.

It’s quite liberating, actually. 

https://t.co/reMxrxkXSG

If you want to be a creator, save more than you think you need to.

Especially take more photos and write more notes — your future self will thank you.

text:
Here's a hint: If you're passionate about an idea, but the  market for articles about it feels uncomfortably small, you may have discovered an intellectual jackpot.

If the idea was obviously popular, somebody would've written about it already — which creates an opportunity.

"How can I be weirder?"

I have good news for you. All of us are weird, but social conditioning makes us suppress our unique interests and character traits.

Building an online audience is about shedding the skin of conditioning and re-discovering what makes you weird.

Having taught more than 500 people to write in the past 18 months, this is one of the hardest ideas for students to wrap their heads around.

We've been trained to ignore our interests so we can please a target audience. Better to write for yourself and let the audience find you.

At the beginning of every podcast episode, @TylerCowen says: "This is the conversation I want to have, not the one you want to have."

The lesson: Weird wins on the Internet. 

Create things for yourself and if it's good, you'll attract an audience of like-minded people.
The biggest mistake new Internet writers is writing about what they think other people want to read instead of following their obsessions

Your ideas will automatically improve as you compress them.

That doesn’t mean that every story needs to focus on the climax. That’d be ridiculous. 

But the process of gathering ideas and distilling them into a smaller, more compressed form is the essence of creative excellence.

Maps can be useful, even if they’re inaccurate. 

In fact, we use distorted maps all the time. 

For years, I didn’t realize that Brooklyn was so much bigger than Manhattan because of the design of the subway map, which makes Manhattan look way bigger than it actually is. https://t.co/9JXC1N23v5
Einstein’s compression is hard to see because it happened in the abstract, but Pablo Picasso showed the same process of compression in concrete form. https://t.co/201m3r6n5j

Einstein once said: “The supreme goal of all theory is to make the irreducible basic elements as simple and as few as possible without having to surrender the adequate representation of a single datum of experience.” 

Things should be made as simple as possible, but no simpler.

RT @the_perell_bot: Biologically, few things are more difficult than holding an opinion everybody you know disagrees with.

Intellectually,…

Making final edits to an essay is like adding jewelry to an outfit.

The basics are already in place but the diamonds of grammar and the sparkle of metaphor make your words shine.
@will_mannon Yes! I’ll be here for this one... be there in an hour 😁

From Thomas Jefferson: A complete education would produce men who were in all ways useful to society — intelligent, cultured, well-informed, technically competent, moral (this particularly), capable of earning a living, happy, and fitted for political and social leadership.

Our best universities should teach us how to live and think.

Historically, America has been unique in its willingness to fund the a liberal arts education while other countries focused on helping students find jobs. 

Save the skill-based training for vocational schools.
Prestigious universities are trying to become vocational schools, but they should double down on their comparative advantage — the Liberal Arts

@Shama Did they have good things to say about the *cutting edge* of information management? 

Or maybe, the principles are entirely timeless. I don’t doubt that the field exists in some form, but I haven’t seen anybody at the frontier of digital ways of thinking

The field needs somebody like @fortelabs.

A person whose ideas can transcend any industry, any company, and any piece of software. Somebody who can give the field new frameworks and a unifying language for thinking clearly about common problems.
@anferneec Even if there’s somebody else studying it, I have no idea who they are so they’re not really successful. Same thing as no competition.

“Isn’t there software for that?”

Yes, but the binding constraint is *ways of thinking* about what group knowledge management should look like in the first place. 

We’ll look back at 2020 and marvel at how little we knew about what’s going to become a very important field.

Here’s a framework for thinking about niches to study:

1) Important part of the economy, so people are willing to pay.

2) Nobody else is studying it, so there’s no competition. 

3) Growing part of the economy, so you can ride a wave.

Group knowledge management hits all three.

I’m spent a lot of time studying  personal knowledge management, and I’ve discovered it’s completely different than group knowledge management because personal knowledge is so embodied.

Personal knowledge management isn’t just facts and figures — it’s memories and intuition too.

Just think of all the companies who struggle to distribute ideas effectively.

You’d work with fast-growing startups and Fortune 500 companies, and both would be willing to pay huge consulting fees.

Plus, it’s a growing sector at the heart of the economy.

There are two kinds of literacy, but we only measure one of them. 

1) Street sign literacy: Being able to read signs and directions, and we’re getting better at this.

2) Library literacy: Being able to understand logic or the nuance in an argument — but we don’t measure this.
Literacy rates may be rising, but people are worse at understanding the Classics than they were 100 years ago

text: @saradietschy Yep

“Should I always do this?”

Nope. 

There are many ways to read, and taking notes while you read undoubtedly lowers the joy of reading. But I suggest writing detailed paragraphs if you’re reading with an end goal in mind — such as writing an essay about the book in your hands.

In practice, this is what one of my notes looks like. 

My reading notes are the first draft of a new thought, but they’re worth capturing because the fidelity of my reflections are strongest while I’m reading. Since I save all my notes, I can always return to these notes too. https://t.co/zGvZKF6n0u

But I prefer the Charlie Munger philosophy: “Take a simple idea and take it seriously.”

Here’s the challenge: Being prolific is an admirable trait, and almost by definition, being formulaic helps you create consistently.

How do you build systems that enable surprise instead of banal predictability?

Any creative endeavor stops being interesting the second it starts being predictable.

Too many creatives let their success turn into a formula.

Biologically, few things are more difficult than holding an opinion everybody you know disagrees with.

Intellectually, it’s one of the strongest skills you can have.

The number of hours I spent golfing in high school would astound you.

Golf was all I did because I dreamed of eventually turning pro. Those years taught me about greatness. Many of the people I played with are professionals now, and I revered how seriously they took their craft.

Some things I do:

• I write for 90 minutes every day.
• I ask my team to critique me whenever I teach.
• I work with a personal writing coach.
• I stretch my mind with serious reading every day.
• I publish a newsletter every Monday and Friday and I’ve never missed a week.

Give knowledge work the same respect that great athletes give their sport.

Train every day, write detailed improvement plans, and surround yourself with people who push you towards excellence.

Humanities education quality has stagnated, if not declined in the past century.

The average Yale grad in 1920 knew more about the classics than the average one today. It’s time to change that. Who is building the modern liberal arts education, outside the walls of academia?
Society no longer believes in the liberal arts, so it’s a great place to turn your attention.

There’s a general principle here: You’ll learn more about people by focusing on the mundane than the sensational. 

People are too quick to stop listening in banal moments where the majority of dialogue happens. Life can be filled with color, even in the dreariest times.

Learning to listen is learning to think beyond conscious speech. 

A good listener will give these throwaway lines the attention they deserve. A great one will listen for what’s not being said. After all, people speak loudest in their quietest moments.
People reveal themselves in throwaway comments, when they’re talking but not thinking about what they’re saying

You can only afford to be in the middle if you're a full-time producer.

But most people have families and work full-time jobs. Those who do should write short "postcards," but spend most of their time creating "permanent assets" that'll create consistent value for a decade.

Far too many creators spend too much time in the middle. 

They spend too much time on ideas that won't stand the test of time, and not enough time on permanent assets that could still be relevant in a decade. As a result, they get stuck on a treadmill of never-ending production.

Online writing falls into one of these two buckets:

1) Permanent Assets: Thoughtful ideas that will compound in value for decades, usually in the form of essays.

2) Postcards: Simple personal updates where you check-in with people, usually in the form of tweets or newsletters.
Good writing isn’t just the result of deep thinking, it’s where deep thinking happens in the first place

text:
When you’re a guest on podcasts, you realize that most interviewers ask you the same damn questions.

Interviewers: Remember, your conversation doesn’t exist in a vacuum.

2. Teaching follows a power law.

Like most of the Internet, there are disproportionate returns to being the best. In public schools, even the best teachers have no more than 100 students at a time. Online, the best teachers can have thousands of students.

Online education is growing fast.

text:
The goal is to prevent Writing Sprawl, where you start with an interesting idea only to realize that everything in the world is connected, and all of a sudden, you need to write a book so you can explain everything you're thinking about.

The Summary Box prevents Writing Sprawl.

If you're struggling to organize your writing, start with a 100-word summary.

Condense your summary into the Summary Box. If an idea doesn't make the cut, add it to the Circle of Distracting Ideas.

If you write only about ideas in the Summary Box, your writing will improve. https://t.co/0IuuBodBcP

Email: Most businesses have one core metric, where everything else works out if you get it right.

For me, that metric is the number of quality email subscribers. Quality is measured by email open rate, the quality of email responses I get, and likelihood to join Write of Passage

I now have a 10-year vision for Write of Passage, which will become the business school of the future. 

I want the community to have the camaraderie of a CrossFit gym, the commitment of CrossFit participants, and the global reach of the CrossFit brand. https://t.co/uNzJMvdsHF

text: Until now, Write of Passage has felt like an experiment. For most of 2019, I mumbled when I spoke about it because the student experience had so much room for improvement. Spurred by the intimidating quality of people in the course, I now speak confidently about the business.

Write of Passage: The school has been a smashing success. I never dreamed that my work would be so fulfilling, especially as a 25-year-old. As a three-person team, we’ve already taught more than 500 people from more than 30 countries how to write this year.

Paradoxically, finding time to read begins with improving operations, which takes away time from deep reading. Or maybe, I’m caught in the same cycle that plagues our society: We keep inventing things that save us time, but it feels like we have less free time than ever before.

Finding the time for deep reading: Building a business makes deep reading difficult because the move-fast neuroticism I need to build Write of Passage is the opposite of the slower, contemplative mindset I need to soak into a 17th-century work of philosophy.

My investment thesis is fueled by rapid improvements in creator-focused tools, such as Stripe, Shopify, and Teachable.

At the same time, intelligent people are under-served by the information economy. Information may be abundant, but high-quality public thinking is scarce.

Angel investing: I don’t know what my investing future looks like, but I enjoy doing it.

I don’t really invest to make money. I do it to learn and support admirable people who work in my areas of interest: education, productivity, and the creator-economy. https://t.co/7Iv8yfMmMk

Why I write: You can’t write 10,000 intelligent words about a topic until an idea has lived in your mind for a long time. 

Whenever I start an essay, the main idea is tangled like a pair of old headphones. I don’t find momentum until I can summarize it in the length of a tweet.

Everybody on our team is an architect with a huge influence over 1000s of students’ experiences, so we must hire brilliant people.

As Alfred Whitehead once said: “Civilization advances by extending the number of important operations which we can perform without thinking of them”

As humans, we should do as little work as possible. 

Our minds should be occupied by systems design, so software can execute tasks on our behalf in a much more cost-effective way. Everybody on our team should look for ways to automate their own work.

text:
Looks like the picture on the left in the tweet above is actually the Oceanografic Aquarium in Valencia, which Felix Candela designed. 

Here are some of his other buildings, which may have also influenced the Sydney Opera House.

(h/t @PerisIdeas) https://t.co/ZqMdw93rUt

Often, the final result is close to my original source of inspiration too. 

For example, the Sydney Opera House was inspired by Candela Church, and the final result has stunning similarities in color, rhythm, and shape. https://t.co/0q3lYzx0yM

All my projects start with a simple idea. Then, they descend into a maddening complexity where I lose faith in the project. Eventually, they become simple again and that's when I publish.

These Sydney Opera house illustrations are a perfect visual representation of my process. https://t.co/3YQGmd0Efz

The three steps of writing an essay:

1) Simple
2) Complex
3) Simple

I usually finish close to where I started, but the writing process refines the original idea.

For example, here are some early photos of Amazon's home page, which I found in less than five minutes. 

Plus you'll learn a lot about Jeff Bezos, who is famous for micro-managing every pixel of the company's home page, at least in the early days. https://t.co/Rn8oJLMPNx

• Little umbrellas 
• Intricate store signage
• Cobblestone streets 
• Charming architecture
• Flower boxes
• No cars

Plus, I like how restaurants and apartments sit on top of each other. https://t.co/ykhGfre0Gn

Add clean sidewalks, warm lighting, and mixed-use zoning, and you have a block I want to visit. https://t.co/LIwjzCn62n
@juvoni That describes @fortelabs well

Creativity comes more from randomness than messiness. 

My best ideas come from obscure ideas, bizarre experiences, and never letting the mundane lose its color. However, I can only squeeze insight out of those moments when my calendar and note-taking systems are in order.

We wrongly assume that messiness leads to creativity. But the opposite is true. Simple and dependable systems allow me to focus on higher-order tasks.

Or, as Gustave Flaubert said: "Be regular and orderly in your life, so that you may be violent and original in your work."
The simpler your productivity systems, the more creative your work can be

I love making drawings for Twitter.

Here's what I've learned about them:

∙ Have a consistent color palette
∙ For clarity, use as few lines as possible
∙ Make the message simpler than you think
∙ Create information hierarchy with font size
∙ Use @ConceptsApp or @Procreate https://t.co/hiprGIG7Oq

"You have to ship something into live production every week — worse case, two weeks. If you just joined, ship something." — @naval

@KyleBowe4 Good point, exactly how I feel

This idea doesn't apply everywhere, but it seems like a general principle for knowledge work.

"Keep breaking your time frames down into smaller chunks. Instead of one twelve-week project, structure it as twelve one-week projects." — @JasonFried https://t.co/YgT5litng8

Small projects build momentum.

Big ones hurt momentum. 

The longer something takes, the less likely you are to finish it, so break big projects into small ones. https://t.co/XHL7snxfwM

text:
Online learning is moving from a passive phase to an active one.

Passive learning:

• Pre-recorded videos
• Passive income
• Pay for content
• Sit back and listen

Active learning:

• Invigorating live sessions
• Full-time staff
• Pay for community
• Sit forward and talk

If you want to follow the growth of Write of Passage, and learn some of what we teach, sign up for my 7-day email course.

https://t.co/IrqeZdd1oa

As for the future of Write of Passage, here are my open questions:

1) How can we create a culture of rigor, commitment, and support?

2) How can we attract the best possible students into the community?

3) How can we enable productive, life-long friendships among our students?

I’m particularly proud to see so many alumni returning. 

In the upcoming cohorts, I want alums to take the community reigns, and step into leadership roles. For example, in this cohort, we have seven alumni mentors (led by @levnaginsky) who will each be running a writing group.

We‘re going to build the business school of the future, without compromising our quality of life.

text:
Will did such an exceptional job that @fortelabs and I hired him full-time to serve as Student Manager for both our courses.

We are a remote company, but meet in person a couple times per year to design the curriculum, plan in three-month increments, and eat delicious food. https://t.co/Vh2Eut82tp

Then, @will_mannon showed up.

That’s when things started improving. A former student, Will called me with a list of things I should improve about Write of Passage. 

Here are his original suggestions, his original job description, and the first two photos we ever took together. https://t.co/nNLdLjyMpf

At times, I was embarrassed about Write of Passage, especially after the 2nd cohort. The student experience wasn’t up to my standards, but I didn’t know how to improve it. I feared that my messy, disorganized mind would kill the business. I incapable of growing the school myself.

Starting a company is lonely, and there were moments of extreme doubt and self-loathing.

Along the way, four people in particular offered tremendous  support and encouragement: @jposhaughnessy, @photomatt, @tylercowen, and @sidharthajha (who served as our Student Manager). https://t.co/aJpk6pGyiY

text:
Just before the first cohort, I hosted a focus group for three friends.

I ordered burritos from my favorite taqueria, and we explored every aspect of the curriculum together in my apartment. All of us doubted the vision, especially me. But a glimmer of faith propelled us. https://t.co/5fFXcUPkZy

The idea began with a phone call to @fortelabs in December 2018.

I pitched him on the idea of working together, and he immediately said yes. Two months later, I flew to Mexico City to design the curriculum and film the course with him.

Nothing would have happened without him. https://t.co/ZTucLOYRE2

The Write of Passage story feels very special tonight.

16 months ago, my online writing school was nothing more than an idea on a napkin. Tonight, we began our 5th cohort with ~300 students from 30 countries, from Singapore, to Panama, to Saudi Arabia.

Here’s our company story.

text:
9. You don't need to be in-person

People who try to compete with YC often try to start a co-working space. But as @sama has said, YC purposefully doesn’t have one. Companies come together once a week. That’s it. That way, companies can build their own identity.

8. Create community, but not too much

Everybody YC founder moves to San Francisco, but the group only gets together once per week, which is long enough to build relationships, but little enough to focus on the task at hand.

7. Marketing is a competitive advantage

Every edition of The Harvard Business Review raises the school's prestige and builds thought leadership. Likewise, @ycombinator has Hacker News — an aggregator that doubles as a public square for software engineers — as a marketing arm.

3. Internet-first communities

Colleges started on real-world campuses and grew towards the Internet, but modern schools start on the Internet and grow towards campuses. Like tomorrow’s schools, the YC experience is live, but alumni stay in touch over the Internet.

2. Project-based learning

Students don't memorize facts and figures. They’re building startups instead. Rate of learning is measured by the rate of a company's progress, and Demo Day serves as a forcing function for founders to take swift action.

LOVE this topic, could talk about it for hours.

If we see time and money as two sides of the same coin, then time spent not making money is wasted. 

Thus, our obsession with productivity has the side-effect of demonizing leisure. But only in leisure can we hear the birds chirping or listen to the echoes of the universe.

The Greeks saw leisure as a time for learning. In fact, the etymology of “school” comes from the Greek word for leisure, skole. 

But the synonymous relationship between school and leisure disappeared in our work-governed, productivity-obsessed world.

Much of modern leisure is slothful. 

It’s spent in a state of passive, shoulders-slumped consumption where we inhale processed foods that make us fat, TV shows that numb instead of inspire, and advertisements that create anxieties that only shopping can relieve.

Time is scarce, and once gone, it disappears forever. 

We all know these things. And yet, at work and at home, we’re so lost in a trance of distraction that killing time has become a chronic disease.

If you’re okay with killing time, it’s not scarce enough.

text:
As the Fowler Brothers once wrote, people prefer concrete words to abstract ones, familiar words to unfamiliar ones, short words to long ones, and Saxon words to Latin ones.

Boris Johnson explains it best in this video. https://t.co/ZrLCGBBYxt

This echoes some famous writing wisdom.

Here's Winston Churchill: “Broadly speaking, short words are best, and the old words, when short, are best of all.”

And this is from Strunk and White: “Anglo-Saxon is a livelier tongue than Latin, so use Anglo-Saxon words.”

English is a combination of two languages.

1) Anglo-Saxon influences, which came from Germany. 

2) Latin speech influences, which came from Italy.

Saxon words are shorter and simpler than Latin ones. 

Here's the takeaway: If you want to write clearly, use more Saxon words. https://t.co/dLbTNzyQa9

text: @JamieRusso In what way?

When writing, focus on counter-intuitive ideas.

Smash people's assumptions and replace them with more useful ways of thinking. If it's intuitive, don't write it.

Here are two ways to improve your storytelling. 

1) The Story Circle: Start and end your story with the same metaphor — close your story where it began.

2) The Story Roller Coaster: Start with positive emotion, then create conflict, then end with a resolution. Up, down, up. https://t.co/OZLntOuH4c

This came from a conversation with my friend Will Mannon, who summarized the idea here.

https://t.co/NHQf7knypQ

After listening to hundreds of podcasts, I've realized that the best answers have a similar arc.

1) State your main point

2) For abstract concepts, use a metaphor

3) Share why your argument is counter-intuitive

4) Tell a story to explain the point

5) Re-state your main point

text:
Progress is limited by people’s inability to identify and communicate what they’re good at.

Ask the average person what they’re good at and they won’t give you a precise answer... even the people who are good at things!

Identifying your strengths is a worthy long-term project.

Great companies focus on their core strengths.

Pixar: Beautiful animations.
Disney: Capturing the imagination.
Facebook: Owning attention.
Apple: Building high-end hardware
Nike: Making high-performance gear.

People have core strengths too.

Learn to communicate yours.
